segments.text: Bob Cornish, I'm in the office of Roberta Burroughs, B-U-R-R-O-U-G-H-S. Roberta, tell us what your title is and what kind of responsibilities you have in the planning department.
I am assistant director for redevelopment.
My responsibilities include housing, economic development, neighborhood planning,
and the Community Development Block Grant.
Okay, that's quite a bit.
Yes.
How many people report to you?
Approximately 34.
What is your academic background?
I have a degree in regional planning, city and regional planning at the Masses level from Cornell.
And I have a sociology degree, a bachelor's degree, from Hampton Institute, now called Hampton University.
In Washington.
It's in Hampton, Virginia.
It's pretty close to Washington.
Okay, where were you before you came to Houston?
At Cornell.
This is your first job right out of school.
Yes, I was an intern here even.
Is that right?
Between my first and second year in graduate school, I was an intern here.
Well, since you've been in Houston, you've also become active in APA.
Could you describe your activities in APA for us?
I have been the local section director twice.
What were those years?
And I'm now the membership chairperson for the state chapter and looking at running for a national board seat.
I haven't decided which one.
What does your division do?
Let me rephrase that.
How do you find you spend most of your time?

I spend most of my time involved with the Community Development Block Grant in one fashion or another, writing and or reviewing guidelines, writing and or reviewing contracts to try to get the money spent.
I spend a lot of time writing, not writing, reviewing neighborhood plans.
I also spend a great deal of time with the small business loan program, either writing or reviewing guidelines for it.
And with the rental rehab program.
I understand that the planning department here
Planning and Development Department now, inherited quite a few programs that I think in your case were the subject of some criminal acts and unfortunate maneuvers by previous employees and whatnot.
Would you like to go into some of that for the record?
The division where the alleged, I guess,
I'm not sure whether they're alleged.
I think people were actually convicted.
I think they were, yeah.
That division was spun off from the department before I inherited the community development responsibilities.
It now resides in the public works department.
So my relationship with them is one of coordination.
So I really am not all that familiar with the facts of what happened.
It's my understanding that
shabby rehab work was being approved in return for bribes.
We kind of cleaned house and set it up in the Public Works Department where we feel it's more appropriately housed because of their role in handling inspections and
Because of their experience and that kind of thing.
So that's what's happened with that.
You have three divisions under you.
Neighborhood planning, CD grant management, and economic development.
Could we talk a little bit about economic development, particularly in view of the depressed economy of Texas and Houston in particular?
We have several programs that are designed to stimulate economic redevelopment in low-moderate income areas, which is an area that encompasses roughly a third of the entire city.
And most of our programs rely upon funding from the Community Development Block Grant.
We have a small business revolving on fund program

the small business owners who are doing business, who are located in one of our low-moderate income areas, they can, the way the program is presently structured, they can apply, business owners can apply for a tandem loan, which means we will make half the loan.
The other half has to come from the bank.
But we are in the process of amending that program because we found that banks are really not
very interested right now in loaning money in the low-model neighborhoods.
So we are amending the program to allow us to make direct loans to small business owners who are located in our areas.
And we can also do facade loans.
Where does this money come from?
That's from the Community Development Block Grant.
That's the source of capital for the program.
We've set aside a million and a half dollars.
And it will revolve.
Payments will revolve back.
And if we run out, we will reprogram community development funds to put more money into it.
Do you charge an interest?
Yes, we're charging 6% interest on those.
The tandem loans, the interest right now is half a prime.
But we're proposing to change that to 6% so we don't have a real mixed portfolio.
So it will all be 6%.
Well, that's quite an interesting program.
Yeah, I'm really excited about that program in particular.
It's something that planners, it's the kind of thing planners don't traditionally get a chance to get involved with.
So I'm learning a lot about banking and lending and being a bank.
We're learning a lot about being a bank because we also service our loans, both housing and small business and
So we're having to learn how to be bankers as well as planners.
Do you have any staff members who have had banking experience?
Yes.
That must be a help.
The small business person does, yeah.
It was hard to find him, too, because our pay scales are not at the bank level.
No.
And we searched for many months, and we have someone we're really happy with.
Well, the climate for planning seems to have
changed with the election of Catherine Whitmer, and then with the appointment of a new planning director.
And of course the size of the staff has more than doubled, and I would expect that morale would be subsequently raised.
with all of these changes and opportunities that have been made available to planners?
I think from the standpoint of people being a lot more able to do the things that they were trained to do in planning school, morale is certainly higher.
Of course, you have to take into account that everyone's pay was cut 3% last year.
So that's almost counterbalanced to all the wonderful changes that are taking place professionally in the professional arena for planters here.
But I think that we're able to see, I know I personally am involved in a lot of things that I had never been involved before, and that's very exciting and challenging.
And that's the case for most everybody.
with the possible exception of our community development people who are more or less doing what they've always done, but I think doing it a lot better.
The year that Ephraim, in fact, the day that Ephraim became planning director, it was announced that the city budget was going to be cut 15%.
So if your salaries were only cut 3%, I suppose that the planning department made out quite well on a
across the board basis.
Not really.

The salaries were cut citywide, and the reason it impaired morale so greatly is because the idea, the city council did that over the mayor's objection, and the idea was the mayor wanted to lay off people, and city council did not want them laid off, so as an alternative, they cut our pay, but people were still laid off.
So the way that people feel city-wide, this isn't just the planning department that was affected, is it was pointless.
People, I think, were willing to make the sacrifice if it meant that their co-workers were kept on the payroll.
But both things happened.
Pay was cut and people were laid off.
Except in the planning department, you added.
We did not lay off anybody.
In fact, you were hiring, weren't you?
And we still are.
We're in a hiring mode right now, even.
Maybe I should apply.

Well, I should probably tell you that the previous personnel director went through and cut all of the pay grades for planners, which is a source of morale among the people whose classification is planner.
So we had on the one hand something that really was designed to raise morale, that had the effect of raising morale.
And then on the other hand, we had this counter
bailing forces, so somehow the personnel department did not get the word that planning was going to be elevated.
Well, maybe between Ephraim and the mayor that could be changed.
Yeah, we're working on it.
The politics are not right right now to raise anybody's pay, but I think it'll happen.
Yeah, probably.
It sounds like it might.
Yeah, it'll happen.
It's just too big an inequity and injustice to not be righted.
Sure.
Let me ask you then, would you have much to do with the new comprehensive planning process?
Yes, by virtue of the fact that the neighborhood planning division is part of this operation.
The neighborhood planners have in fact been working for about a year on neighborhood plans, and there are three that are in the draft stage, so we'll be able to move
fairly quickly with those three plans through this whole process of review and adoption.
And it's very, it's really good.
I came here in 73 as a neighborhood planner.
And the frustration that we had, those of us who were neighborhood planners at that time, was that the plans were not tied to any kind of implementation mechanism.
But now they will be tied to the CIP, and also the CDBG money is under the purview of this department.
So to have a neighborhood plan and CDBG in the same department really helps when you talk about getting the plans implemented, because we have the money to implement them.
And then also you have your new development ordinance.
Right.
Yeah.
And that would provide a certain amount of guidance.
Yeah, that will have less of an impact on us because there isn't a lot of new development that will take place in our areas.
And the development ordinance really guides, sets forth, codifies standards for new development.
So actually, the planning resolution is what will impact us more, which is council will actually adopt the plans, which means they'll feel some ownership in them.
Some identification.
Yeah.

Of course, there's been quite a shift in policy direction in the city, away from what was almost exclusively attention to the New Grove fringe areas, to the inward-looking redevelopment and recycling of inner-city land and the land that had been passed over.
Of course, that's where your interests lie, as I understand it.
And this, of course, would have
consequences for inner city densities and for commute patterns, which I guess would be in line with what Metro is doing at the moment and whatnot.
Yeah, we actually, again, because we have the money to put behind the philosophy, we won't be able to have a great deal of influence on redevelopment by paying for it or creating

incentives we have most of our economic development programs are leveraging programs they're designed to leverage private sector involvement so as to make the money go further so we have a whole package of incentives and the small business was one i touched on earlier we also have a tax abatement ordinance that we're using extensively to create in these revitalization areas tax abatement districts
And then we have what we call a targeted opportunity program where we can fund major projects in the inner city areas that create jobs.
So we have a whole package of incentives that are available.
I'm interested in public housing.
And I don't see anything down here called public housing in your organizational chart.
No, the Houston Housing Authority is a separate entity in Houston.
with a separate board.
You have Housing Finance Corporation under your Economic Development Division.
That's about as close as you come to public housing, I would suppose.
Yes, and that's not public housing.
That entity issues mortgage revenue bonds, and we coordinate with them.
The other three that are listed there, we actually provide staff support.
The tax exempt bond issuers.
Well, the Housing Authority, maybe I'm talking to, I should talk with them, but I was just wondering, you must know what their plans are for an Allen Parkway housing project.
I know they plan to sell it.
It's occupying very valuable land.
Yes.
And Ephraim was saying that they haven't been putting people into it for several years.
And by attrition, it has become almost exclusively housed by Vietnamese.
And that they're hoping to construct their own
or come up with their own cooperative housing.
Some of this seems to be quite innovative.
Yes, this will be the first co-op housing that's been done in Houston.
And it's another thing we're really excited about.
And everything seems to be falling into place.
HUD is committed.
We're committed.
We have interested developers.
It should happen.
As far as I know, the Housing Authority hasn't gotten any official word from HUD as to whether they'll be able to sell the project.
But it's my understanding that they are making plans to house people in other parts of the city in scattered site housing, though.
Actually, that's the philosophy.
It's still scattered sites.
Yeah.
They don't want to do any more of those giant projects, which are kind of hard to keep up.
It puts all of the people who have problems in one place.
Well, it institutionalizes people.
Right.
You know, that's the sad part of it.
They just feel caught up in something they can't break out of.
Well, okay.
Are there any other points you'd like to bring up for the history of planning in Houston?
I've seen four mayors come and go.
Who were they?
When I came, Louis Welch was mayor.
He represented the Chamber of Commerce.
Well, when he left here, he went to work for the Chamber of Commerce.
Some say that he worked for the Chamber of Commerce while he was mayor.
Some have said that, but I didn't say that.
I'll never say it.
And then who followed him?
Hoffines followed him, then McCann.
Hoffines had two terms?
Yeah.
And McCann had two, I believe.
And this is the second term.
He's bankrupt now.
He's what?
He's bankrupt now.
Did he declare bankruptcy?
Yeah, that's according to Ethan.
Yeah, I saw him the other day at a fundraiser, but I didn't.
Maybe he's raising funds to get out.
Well, there was a fundraiser for the council members.
And then, of course, Catherine.
Yeah, yeah.
And then you served under Roscoe.
Did you have the same area of responsibility with Roscoe?
No, I was the manager when he left of the neighborhood revitalization division.
So I had been, I came as a neighborhood planner, and so that's been predominantly my work experience.
My responsibilities expanded.
I was promoted.
And my responsibilities expanded, so I was exposed for the first time to the block grant.
And to housing programs, I had a lot of housing experience that I never had.
And also economic development, that was totally new.
What happened is, under the previous mayors, the economic development division was part of the mayor's office.
And so was the community development division.
So what happened is all those got merged and I inherited them.
I was the lucky winner.
But it's been a real good experience for me.
I like it.
Oh, yeah.
I would think so.
I like it a lot.
That would be very challenging.
Yeah.
In different ways.
Yeah, a lot of different ways.
Well, Roberta, I want to thank you for your time.
You're welcome.

You'll be getting a transcript of this whenever we can get around to doing it, and then I would like to ask you to review and make any corrections or additions that come to your mind at that time, and return it as soon as you can.
As you know, I'm trying to get a draft together for
the chapter conference in Houston next year.
And I'll have to start writing it well in advance of the actual meeting.
Oh, yes.
So getting all this put together is going to be quite a task.
Yeah.
Thank you for your participation.
Oh, you're welcome.
Is planning history kind of a niche of yours?
I teach at A&M.
Do you know John Rapps?
Yes, very well.
Do you?
I was at a reception for him in April when they had it during the APA conference in New York.
Oh, yes.
And I hadn't seen him since 73.
So I figured you might know him and that you might be friends since you're in the same area since I don't imagine there are a lot of people in that area playing him.
Well, I was responsible for his invitation to our centennial at Texas A&M, and he gave
by far the best presentation for a college.
Then we're both members of the Society for American City and Regional Planning History.
And he's been a big help to me.
Thank you.
You're welcome.
It's June 26.
We're in the office of Mike Davis at Metro in Houston.
Mike, what is your title?
I'm an environmental planner, environmental planner three.
OK. What do you do in Metro?
I'm involved with assisting in developing environmental impact statements, environmental assessments on any capital projects that Metro does that involve expenditure of federal funds.
That's the environmental clearance process.
OK. Why don't you give us a quick rundown on Metro, how it came into being?
what its mission is and what its funding is.
Okay, why don't we hold?
Okay.
So your mission and your funding.
Okay, the organization was created after a local referendum where voters were asked if they wished to dedicate an extra penny sales tax to fund mass transit in Houston.
When was that?
This was in 1978.
The referendum passed, and we've been operating since that time.
Metro was formerly known as Hugh Tran and was part of the city of Houston, operated as the transit department of the city of Houston, and had a seriously deteriorated fleet.
It was a typical transit kind of development historically.
The first transit in Houston was mule-pulled trolleys on rail tracks that progressed to a full streetcar system that was run by a variety of owners.
I think most of it was probably developed by Stone and Webster Engineering.

And then eventually, just the historical pattern, I'm sure it's not much different in any city, where the slowly after World War II buses became more popular because of their effectiveness in the suburbanization trend.
Eventually, the system became severely deteriorated.
And this is typical.
The city took it over, operated it in a pretty shabby state because of lack of revenue from the system.
And then I don't know.
This report will document it much better than I can date-wise.
There were some stirrings for improvements to the mass transit system over the years, and that eventually led to the 1978 referendum, which created Metro as a Metropolitan Transit Authority.
This document... Then, after the authority was created, there were some problems with the directors, as I recall.
There were a whole...
series of executive directors.

The executive director that was on board at the time the organization was created left not soon thereafter, and there were some allocation, some problems with what was perceived as extravagance among the administrative levels of the organization.
I wasn't here at the time, I don't know how much of that is true, but I do remember the perceptions, just at that time I was
I guess in graduate school myself.
At A&M.
At A&M.
And there seems to have been some extravagances.

I would think it would have been just a very heady time just to suddenly have promised an incredible mission and have your funding source secure a relatively inadequate source of funding to enable you to do things right.
So I'm sure there could well have been some excesses.
I'm not the one to speak to that.
I have no proof other than reading it in the papers a long time ago.
But the important thing is, overall, the system has improved dramatically from its deteriorated state, where we're now one of the best.
We are about the best bus transit system for a major city in the US.
Seattle's doing quite well, too.
I think the rankings are just out on the wards.
The American Public Transit Association gives that every year.
And we continue to receive high marks because we're running about 98% on-time performance, which is an incredible increase.
The miles between road calls on our buses have increased in excess of the 100,000 mile mark, and it used to be like 50 miles or whatever.
So the statistics prove that the organization has become
a very good, solid, dependable bus transit system.
And a lot of the problems that you experienced for a few years were problems over which the organization had no control, such as the new buses that kept breaking.
Well, the issue there was one of the largest priorities in what Metro defined they needed to do when they were proposing the sales tax referendum was to get
acceptable maintenance facilities online.
There was just no provision for maintenance.
The old Milby Bus Barn site, you know, used since the horse-drawn days, was the only facility that was there.
There was no way to maintain the bus, even if you had the money at that time.
So one of the earliest projects to go into effect was building a cashmere operating facility.
It's a heavy maintenance facility, which is an incredible facility.
Well, I think my point is, too, that it wasn't the problem.
It wasn't generated by the city, but because of their lack of maintenance facilities, but by the designer of the buses.
That was one issue.
Some of the buses, some of the earliest buses bought from Metro and the ones that were inherited from the huge .
The frames would break.
Were the flexibles that had severe problems.
A lot of re-engineering went into them.
And then aside from those problems,
The buses couldn't air condition enough to keep the system cool.
And the big priority was to make the system efficient and rideable.
And there was no way to cool the buses.
And the air conditionings on those things were rebuilt time after time.
The problem was eventually solved.
Some major re-engineering that the manufacturer had to take on and pick up the tab for.
But some of those buses are still in use.
And they actually function.
The one I ride on, the 82 Westheimer route, is an old bus from that vintage.
And it will freeze you to death.
And so they do work.
We have what's called a hot box at Cashmere, which generates excessive temperatures.
And before buying a bus, we test it in that box.
We superheat it to the equivalent of being 130 degrees inside.
And we time it on how long it takes it to cool down to a comfort level for a person to be sitting in the bus.
And that facility is used by other transit organizations in the US who are testing buses.
So we've been able to develop those kind of facilities to make sure the system functions.
One of the things I have for you here to keep on track is this particular document.
It's the document that was developed
Metro, metropolitan transit for Harris County.
State of July 78.
July 78.
This document lists the regional transit plan.
This is the plan that was prepared to promote the creation of the transit authority, and this is the guide that we began with, the initial comprehensive plan, you might say.
This document gives you a proposal of the kind of system
that we want to build and announce the existing conditions, and proposes the major issues that we should address.
And in going through this document, you'll get an idea.
There's developing ideas like developing the Contra Flow Lane, which was put into use very early, developing permanent transit facilities and the means of freeways, which is a project that
At the end of our current five-year capital improvement plan, we'll have 69 miles of those facilities.
They're going in all over the place now.
We're building now on Gulf Freeway 29 to the northwest, North Freeway, the Katy, and we're in design on the final design.
We've had environmental clearance to build the one on the southwest freeway.
Nothing on the southern freeway?
The South Freeway.
South Freeway.
South Freeway is proposing a lot of, it's included as one of the facilities, a facility probably, I believe it's a phase three project.
It would be included also one on the East Texas Freeway, which is 59 North.
Potentially a facility would be included there.
The Highway Department is working on
initiating a widening project on East Tech's now, and the cross-section they're acquiring will include enough right-of-way for a median bus line in the middle of the freeway.
So those are long-range.
You must have a good working relationship with the Division of Highways.
Of course, we all coordinate through what we always call the 3C planning process.
The Houston-Galveston
Council, the local H2C, is the MPO, the Metropolitan Planning Organization for Houston area.
And everything coordinates through that.
All our projects that we're proposing go through the clearance process to be included on their unified work program, to be on the transportation improvement program.
So that everything is coordinated there.
We have a good relationship with them, of course, because we have to have their permission to be in.
right-of-ways of freeways and state highways.
And that hasn't been a problem.
The Southwest Freeway Transitway that's being built is a cooperative project with the Highway Department.
At the time they're upgrading the freeway, we'll be constructing the transitway itself.
So it's a two-fold project.
Upon completion, the freeway will have been rehabilitated in the transitway.
And there's also
There's an organization that is referred to as the Super Group, which is the occasional meeting of the big guys, like the mayors of Houston.

our general manager, Mr. Keeper, and Mr. Lanier of the Highway Commission, and all the folks who are managing the organizations that affect the transportation system, who meet on a relatively regular basis to assure there's coordination.
Oh, gosh.

I can't remember how long ago the Houston Chamber of Commerce initiated the regional mobility plan, which is sort of like a wish list of all the transportation projects that would be needed to improve travel times and to reduce congestion.
I think they targeted a 1978 level of congestion when the project was started to bring travel times back to those parameters.
So that's also a coordinating project that the regional mobility committee meets on a continual basis.
And we consider the regional transit plan, which has now been adopted by the board, to be a component of that overall plan, too.
So the coordination, I think, is working very well.
We also, you probably discussed with Mr. Garcia about the new comprehensive planning process.
Right.
I have that down pat.
Okay.
You know, Metro's involved in that as on the technical advisory committee.
So I feel that coordination goes pretty well.
We also, one of our missions as a transit authority is to assist in what we call TSM, Transportation System Management Projects.
which will improve travel times for our buses.
These are street-level improvements to the existing transportation system.
We initially committed, and the 78 document commits, about $150 million to cooperative projects with the city of Houston, Harris County, and the other municipalities in our metro region.
to do those improvements.
So we are tied in with the city of Houston's capital improvement program as a funding source and a cooperative builder of a lot of the improvements in their transportation.
Yes.
Roberta mentioned that.
And it was quite surprising to me to hear that Metro was actually helping to reconstruct some of the city streets.
We've done some major projects.

grade separations or a lot of them in the construction of West Park which is a major thoroughfare with grade separations and grade separations over railroad tracks and some intersections and that's a continuing project that benefits us by getting our buses a non congested route or a route that's not
doesn't suffer the vagaries of the railroad schedule, because that obviously would ruin your ability to maintain a reliable schedule for a bus if it's got to wait for a railroad crossing.
We identified in this plan we were discussing earlier, the 78 plan, identifies potential locations for all of the joint capital projects that we're proposing.
And we recently looked over a document
We made a report to the board of directors on how close we've come to fulfilling this initial plan, and I think we've done a very good job.
The board recently, within the last three or four months, approved an update of the joint projects list.
And so that continues.
One of the things going on right now with the city of Bel Air, I don't know if you've talked to Sarah Janer, and they're working on their tax increment reinvestment zone.
to revive their little five-point or seven-point intersection that's their downtown.
Metro's contributing in that project, and we're building a transit center in the middle of that project.
So it's part of the street reconstruction and bus routing improvements that they're doing there.
So the coordination part, I think, is being handled very well.
It appears to be handled much better than I think the general perception of the public allows.
Maybe the media have been doing as much as they could in terms of indicating how well things are working.
They always report on when things seem to fail.
Building a project, getting it done on time, in budget, that sort of thing is not news work.
No.
Only if it's racked with
You know, structural problems, fraud.
Yeah.
Yeah.
Unless it's bad, it doesn't get sensational coverage.
Criminal acts.
Yeah.
You know, because pretty much our evaluation shows that we're building things on our capital projects.
We're doing well.
We're living up to our commitments.
Only revisions that time in engineering and planning approve.
There's some cases where a project
just isn't going to work as it was originally proposed when you get down to, you know, specific planning.
In most cases, our capital projects are going as proposed.
Our operations have improved dramatically, as we were discussing before.
Reduction in the number of accidents and improvements in service and on-time performance and the fact that the buses are clean and safe and we operate our own security force.
Do you have any radio communication on your buses?
All the buses are tied to a communication system.
And the bus system is completely connected.
They all have two-way radios.
They can communicate back and forth.
If there's a problem on a bus, it can be relayed to a central communications center that's located out at our cashmere maintenance facility.
From that location, they handle dispatching the transit police if it's a security problem.
Or, you know, maintenance issues are handled there.
In a case if a bus breaks down on Post Oak, you can call in immediately and a substitute bus can be sent out to deal with the problem.
You know, or other buses can be rerouted
from their route to pick up the patrons to reduce the lag time.

What we're also doing, we have a major capital project that's a surveillance control system that we're building on the Katy Freeway, which will be an infrared communication system that will allow you to monitor the entire length of the transitway.
with on-site cameras for security purposes and to see if vehicles are broken down on the transit way and to monitor the location of the vehicle.
So it will be a major system that hopefully will eventually be extended to all the transit centers.
Has Metro considered other modes of transportation?
Sure.
In developing the regional plan, which this first document reflects and which some of these later reports get you into more specific analysis of the regional plan, a technology assessment was done.
And a lot of different technologies have been looked at.
The basic conclusion of that assessment is that we will remain primarily a bus system.

Even given our current proposal where phase two would be a system connector linking transit centers and transit ways and local routes, that would be about 14 miles of light rail, surface rail with overhead electric power source.
Even given that scenario, we will still be primarily a bus system with approximately 2,000 miles worth of local routes operating in our region.
There are areas where congestion warrants, travel time warrants,
potential ridership and operations savings warrant building some fixed guideways and that's what the board's currently mulling over in phase two in what in the quarter we're evaluating now.
With the changed focus of
the new planning and development department under Captain Whitmer toward infills within the inner city and more attention to redevelopment and recycling of land closed in.
That might be building densities that would be more amenable to fixed rail than would have been historically the case.
This is a real difficult issue and it continues to plague the board and they're trying to make a decision about the actual nuts and bolts of what our regional system will look like.
That density issue is, I think, an interesting one.
I'm not sure
that even to our current planning horizons of year 2000 to year 2010, that that will make a major difference.
It comes down to looking at primarily the biggest demand upon our transit system will be
home-based work trips, commuting from home to work, regardless of where home is, whether it's inner city or suburban.
And providing that service requires looking at activity centers that are developed and providing service to them.
In the course of doing that, I think you can adequately provide service to major activity centers to people inner city through the local system.

And then for the congested corridors, the freeway corridors, getting people from the suburbs into activity centers, which are primarily downtown, the uptown City Post Oak area, the Greenway Plaza area, and the Texas Medical Center.
Those are our primary activity centers.
Serving those areas, we need the transitways, the fixed guideways, to get you from suburban locations into these areas and to get you between them.
the local route system that's developed feeds into that proposed grander system of fixed guideways and provides really good travel times.
So I think even given to sum up the highest densification you could predict based on that planning initiative, the comprehensive planning process,
I think the local routes would still provide the best service.
Because if it is a dense system, it needs frequent stops.
And frequent stops would not likely justify a heavy capital fixed guideway system.
To achieve some kind of operating cost and increase your speed and efficiency, you have to limit the number of stops that are made.
One thing I should probably do to just
get us on track is we went through several planning refinements based on this toward the board's development of a regional transit plan.
